is the county seat of Calloway County, is on highway U.S. 641 in

, just a few miles from the Kentucky-Tennessee state line, and best known as the home of Murray State University, a well-regarded public liberal arts school. Apart from the university, two of the major industries here are Briggs and Stratton, which makes small engines and Pella, manufacturing fine windows & doors. There are over a dozen smaller companies located in the community. However, the city is dominated by Murray State University. The inventor of radio, Nathan B. Stubblefield, was a native of Calloway County. The first demonstration of radio was held on the courthouse square in Murray in 1902. Murray/Calloway County is a Rand McNally top-rated retirement community.
US 641 is the main travel corridor and provides access from the north and south.  Access from the east and west is provided by KY 94.

value: features several days of festivities (including a concert featuring a top country music act) centered around the Fourth of July.
The Murray-Calloway County Community Theater's Playhouse
in the Park is one of the oldest community theaters in the state. It is housed in the historic (1907) L&N Freight Depot, now located in the heart of the city park.

is one of the highest rated liberal arts schools in the Southeastern United States, brings a unique cultural element to the city.  The school supports athletic teams, known as

, in six men's sports, eight women's sports, and one coeducational sport (rifle shooting). The best-known Racers team is the men's basketball team, a perennial invitee to the NCAA basketball tournament.

Until very recently, Murray was what's known as "moist", as opposed to "dry"â€”meaning that while you could not purchase alcohol in a store, you could (and still can) buy it by the drink.  While this may seem a bit antiquated, it's better than the alternative. Under the previous law, there were no "bars" per se, as any establishment wishing to sell alcohol had to seat at least 100 & derive 70% of its income from food.

On July 17, 2012, Murray voted itself completely "wet". Due to waiting periods required under state law, package liquor sales will not be allowed until the fall, most likely October. Package beer sales can begin once the city passes a governing ordinance, which should take place within the next month. It remains to be seen whether beer in restaurants will be as cheap as it was under the old law.

Several local restaurants (Big Apple, The Keg, El Mariachi Loco....) that had licenses to sell by the drink under the previous law will still be happy to help you quench your thirst. With the new law, bars will soon be able to open, and smaller restaurants that couldn't get alcohol licenses can now apply for them.
